title: You Need to Take Care of Your Front End!
chief_complaint: I've noticed a gradual decrease in my ability to hear in noisy social environments and I have ringing in both ears. I'm finally ready to try hearing aids because the problems are increasing.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral tinnitus; difficulty hearing monitors while singing ballads.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty understanding speech in noise; dissatisfaction with monitor levels during musical performance.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Ready to try hearing aids after previously declining them.

history.present_illness: Patient is a semiretired rock musician reporting gradual hearing loss and tinnitus. No diplacusis or pitch perception difficulties reported.
history.otologic_history: Denies otalgia or vertigo. Normal middle ear function.
history.noise_exposure_history: Rock musician. Sound levels typically 88 dBA to sustained periods >100 dBA. Sound engineer uses sound level meter.
history.prior_management: Seen twice previously for annual exams; hearing aids recommended but declined until now.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetric slight to severe sensorineural hearing loss, sharply falling beyond 500 Hz. Consistent with presbycusis and music exposure.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Slight (Right) to mild (Left) loss in SRT. Excellent word recognition ability bilaterally at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE)
tests.key_findings: Responses present up to 1,000 Hz; absent above 1,000 Hz. Suggests good outer hair cell function in low frequencies.

tests.name: Acoustic Reflex Thresholds
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral ARTs were consistent with audiometric thresholds. Contralateral ARTs could not be performed due to limitations of the equipment.

numeric_results.Right_Ipsi_Thresholds: 500 Hz: 95, 1000 Hz: 100, 2000 Hz: Absent, 4000 Hz: Absent dB HL
numeric_results.Left_Ipsi_Thresholds: 500 Hz: 90, 1000 Hz: 100, 2000 Hz: Absent, 4000 Hz: Absent dB HL

history.present_illness: Fitting of bilateral nonoccluding RIC hearing aids with custom earmolds.
history.prior_management: Hearing aids ordered with treble clef (right) and bass clef (left) on earmolds.
history.patient_goals: Verify hearing aid performance with music.

tests.name: Real Ear Measurement (REM)
tests.key_findings: Measured real ear insertion gain (REIG) closely matched NAL-NL1 targets for 50, 65, and 75 dB SPL inputs.

tests.name: Subjective Music Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Patient played tambourine. Reported sound was 'useless', 'fuzzy', and 'distorted'. Reducing MPO did not resolve the issue. Identified as front-end clipping due to high peak input levels of the instrument exceeding A/D converter headroom.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral symmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with excellent word recognition scores. While standard hearing aid programming provided audibility for speech matching NAL-NL1 targets, the patient experienced significant distortion when playing the tambourine. This was identified as 'front-end' distortion, where the high peak input level of the percussion instrument (110 dB SPL) exceeded the dynamic range of the hearing aid's analog-to-digital converter.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is concentrated in the high frequencies, which affects clarity, but your ability to understand speech remains excellent when it is loud enough.

The distortion you hear with the tambourine is not because the hearing aid is 'broken', but because the instrument's volume spike (peak input) is too loud for the hearing aid's digital entrance (A/D converter).
Think of the hearing aid input like a doorway; the tambourine is too tall to fit through without hitting its head (clipping/distortion).
We need to use specific technology for your music: either a device with a higher input ceiling or a microphone setting that reduces sensitivity to prevent this 'front-end' clipping.
Continue to use hearing protection during high-volume performances to preserve your remaining hearing.
notes_for_actor: You are a knowledgeable musician; you understand sound levels and use a sound level meter.
You are initially skeptical of the hearing aids during the fitting because the tambourine sounds terribleâ€”describe it as 'fuzzy' or 'distorted'.
You are not complaining about loudness, but about quality/clarity of the music.
You are motivated to hear better but will not accept a device that ruins the sound of your music.
